By Megan Costello

data.text:
By Megan Costello

I feel like Ava Cochrane is in my head right now as I wrestle her gigantic scrapbook into the flatbed scanner and compile 45MB TIFF files. Today we are digitizing photos from 1905-1909. Lots and lots of images.

As my instavideo shows, the above dance card -- from a dance at her sorority in Chi Omega -- comes from her senior year in 1908-09. She tongue-in-cheek writes below the dance card, “‘Tis not the first time."

Ha, ha, Ava.

Here's a little window into our socialite: She danced. A lot.

Back in the day, women kept small booklets known as "dance cards."

The cards were handed out at specific dances. Women recorded who they danced with and what dances they shared. Some dance cards even have small pencils attached via ribbon (!). They're adorably cute and small. I plan to blog more about them soon.

For Ava, her dance cards are incredibly detailed. She kept really, really good notes. (Notice how she even wrote the fraternity letters next to each beau? Kind of amazing.)

And, it's no wonder that her waist was so small ... by my counts she danced roughly forty times a week.

The next time I hit up a dance club in Madison, I think I'll bring a dance card along and fill it out. What do you think?

This project is part of a practicum conducted by School of Library & Information Studies master’s candidate Megan Costello. (You can follow her along as she documents some of the more candid snapshots at Megan in (UW)-Madison or on Twitter at @meggo_costello.)
